questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High Hypermetropia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Low Hypermetropia : Hypermetropia ( farsightedness ) occurs when the eye is too short or the lens is too weak , causing light to focus behind the retina . However, the absence of the lens in aphakia leads to a much more significant refractive error than what would be classified as "low" hypermetropia .

  • • Option B
  • • Low Myopia
  • • too long
  • • too strong
  • • front of the retina
  • • Option D. High Myopia : As mentioned, aphakia generally does not lead to myopia. The condition results in a loss of refractive power , not an excess of it, which would be necessary to cause high myopia.
  • • Option D. High Myopia
  • • loss of refractive power

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An optician prescribes a power of -3.00DS / -0.50DC x 180°. The type of astigmatism noted is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Compound Myopic Astigmatism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Spectacles for astigmatism have 3 components: Spherical lens: Concave (-) or Convex (+) power expressed as Dioptre Sphere (DS) . Cylindrical lens: Concave (-) or Convex (+) power expressed as Dioptre Cylinder (DC) . Cylindrical axis . In the given question, the prescription is -3.00DS / -0.50DC x 180° . Concave spherical lens of -3D power indicates the rays from this meridian focus in front of the retina . Cylindrical lens of -0.5D power indicates the rays from this meridian also focus in front of the retina . Axis of the cylinder is at 180°. As mentioned in the table above, if rays from both the meridian focus in front of the retina, it is a case of Compound myopic astigmatism .

questions.text: A 12-year-old female student complains of experiencing blurred vision and difficulty seeing objects in the distance. On examination, her eyes appeared normal with vision of 6/6 in both eyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pseudo Myopia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Index myopia refers to myopia caused by changes in the refractive index of the lens or other ocular media, often related to metabolic changes , and would not usually resolve to show a normal vision of 6/6 during an eye examination.
  • • Option A
  • • myopia
  • • changes
  • • refractive index
  • • lens
  • • metabolic changes
  • • Option C . Simple myopia, or true myopia, is a permanent change in the eye where the eyeball is too long relative to the focusing power of the cornea and lens . This would usually result in a permanent decrease in distance vision , not intermittent symptoms.
  • • Option C
  • • permanent change
  • • eyeball
  • • too long relative
  • • focusing power
  • • cornea
  • • lens
  • • permanent decrease
  • • distance vision
  • • Option D . Induced myopia can be caused by various factors, including medications , increased blood sugar levels , or exposure to various environmental factors . Like index myopia, it would not typically present with normal vision during an examination.
  • • Option D
  • • medications
  • • increased blood sugar levels
  • • exposure
  • • various environmental factors

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient had a refractive error of -5D in the right eye and -7.5D in left eye. The difference in size of retinal image would be.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 5%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above condition is suggestive of ANISOMETROPIA – unequal refraction in both eyes . 1D difference between two eyes produces 2% difference in retinal image . Difference of more than 2.5D causes more than 5% difference in retinal images of the two eyes. Up to 5% can be tolerated. Here, since difference is 2.5D , the retinal images will differ by 5%.
  • • The above condition is suggestive of ANISOMETROPIA – unequal refraction in both eyes .

  • • more than 2.5D
  • • more than 5% difference
  • • 5% can be tolerated.
  • • Here, since difference is 2.5D , the retinal images will differ by 5%.
  • • 2.5D
  • • 5%.
  • • By taking into account the magnification factor for lenses, which for myopic correction is approximately given by the formula:
  • • Magnification=11−(0.014×Lens Power in Diopters)
  • • Magnification=1−(0.014×Lens Power in Diopters)1​
  • • For both eyes, we will calculate the magnification factor and then determine the percentage difference in image size based on these magnification factors. Let's perform this corrected calculation. ​​
  • • magnification factor
  • • percentage difference
  • • image size
  • • The corrected calculation shows that the difference in size of the retinal image between the two eyes is approximately 3.9% , which would be closest to option D, 5%.
  • • 3.9%
  • • closest to option D, 5%.
  • • Students do not need to learn this calculation. The approximations mentioned in the table are clinically relevant and need to be remembered.

questions.text: The site of placement of this segment is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intrastromal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Descemet’s Membrane - This is a thin but strong film of tissue that serves as the protective barrier between the corneal stroma and the endothelial layer of the cornea . It is not suitable for the placement of INTACS as it is too deep and its integrity is crucial for the health of the endothelial cells that are responsible for keeping the cornea dehydrated and transparent.

INTACS are not placed here because the epithelial layer is too thin and constantly regenerates, which would not provide a stable position for the rings.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man came to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of gradually increasing blurring of vision in both his eyes since 1 year. After examination, he was diagnosed with bilateral mature senile cataract and was explained how his lenses had lost their transparency leading to blurring of vision. Factors that play significant role in maintaining the outstanding clarity of normal lens are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vascularity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The lens is covered by a single layer of epithelial cells on its anterior surface . These cells are essential for lens growth and transparency . They help regulate water and ion balance in the lens and produce lens fibers , which are crucial for maintaining lens clarity .

  • • maintaining lens clarity
  • • Option B. Lens has natural auto oxidation mechanism .
  • • Option B.
  • • natural auto oxidation mechanism
  • • Option D. The lens contains ion channels and pumps that help maintain its dehydration and precise ion balance , which are essential for lens transparency . Disruption in this pump mechanism can lead to cataract formation .
  • • Option D.
  • • ion channels
  • • pumps
  • • dehydration
  • • precise ion balance
  • • lens transparency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The lens is an avascular structure , meaning it lacks blood vessels . This avascularity is crucial for its transparency . If the lens were vascularized , the blood vessels would interfere with light transmission and clarity .

questions.text: In the lens, what is/are the pathway(s) involved in the metabolism of glucose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle ) is a key metabolic pathway that generates energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins . However, in the lens , the Krebs cycle plays a minimal role because the lens operates in a relatively hypoxic environment and relies more on anaerobic glycolysis for its energy requirements .
  • • Option A.
  • • citric acid cycle
  • • TCA cycle
  • • metabolic pathway
  • • generates energy
  • • oxidation
  • • acetyl-CoA
  • • carbohydrates, fats,
  • • proteins
  • • lens
  • • Krebs cycle
  • • minimal role
  • • operates
  • • relatively hypoxic environment
  • • relies
  • • anaerobic glycolysis
  • • energy requirements
  • • Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway) , also known as the pentose phosphate pathway , is an important metabolic pathway in the lens . It provides the lens with NADPH , which is crucial for maintaining reduced glutathione levels . Reduced glutathione is vital for protecting the lens against oxidative stress , thus helping maintain its transparency and preventing cataract formation .
  • • Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway)
  • • pentose phosphate pathway
  • • metabolic pathway
  • • lens
  • • NADPH
  • • crucial
  • • reduced glutathione levels
  • • Reduced glutathione
  • • protecting
  • • against oxidative stress
  • • maintain
  • • transparency
  • • preventing cataract formation
  • • Option C. Sorbitol Pathway , also known as the polyol pathway , involves the conversion of glucose to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase . In the lens, this pathway becomes particularly active in hyperglycemic conditions , such as in diabetes , and can lead to the accumulation of sorbitol . Excessive accumulation of sorbitol can cause osmotic stress , leading to lens swelling , opacification , and cataract formation .
  • • Option C. Sorbitol Pathway
  • • polyol pathway
  • • conversion
  • • glucose
  • • sorbitol

  • • lens swelling
  • • opacification
  • • cataract formation

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Functional Hypermetropia occurs in which of the nerve palsy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oculomotor nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) : This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle , which primarily contributes to the rotation of the eye. Trochlear nerve palsy affects eye movement but does not directly impact accommodation or refractive status like hypermetropia.
  • • Option B. Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV)
  • • superior oblique muscle
  • • rotation
  • • eye movement
  • • Option C . Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) : The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle , which is responsible for abduction . Palsy of this nerve leads to an inability to move the eye laterally , but it does not affect accommodation or cause hypermetropia.
  • • Option C
  • • Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI)
  • • lateral rectus muscle
  • • abduction
  • • inability
  • • move
  • • eye laterally
  • • Option D. Optic Nerve (Cranial Nerve II) : The optic nerve transmits visual information from the retina to the brain . Palsy or damage to the optic nerve affects vision, but it does not cause hypermetropia as it is not involved in the accommodation process.
  • • Option D. Optic Nerve (Cranial Nerve II)
  • • transmits visual information
  • • retina
  • • brain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Functional hypermetropia can occur as a result of oculomotor nerve ( Cranial Nerve III ) palsy , which impairs the ciliary muscle's ability to accommodate , leading to difficulty focusing on near objects .
  • ➤ oculomotor nerve
  • ➤ Cranial Nerve III
  • ➤ palsy
  • ➤ impairs
  • ➤ ciliary muscle's ability
  • ➤ accommodate

  • ➤ near objects

questions.text: A patient with high myopia asks for thinner glasses. What is the ideal refractive index of the glass material that can be used?

  • • 2.57

  • ➤ For patients with high myopia seeking thinner glasses , lenses made of high-index materials , such as those with a refractive index of 1.67 , are ideal . They offer a thinner and lighter solution compared to standard lens materials .
